p: The enzyme integrase catalyzes strand transfer (3â€²-end joining), which inserts both viral DNA ends into a host cell chromosome during proviral DNA integration [ 5, 88]. Once integrated, the provirus persists in the host cell genome and functions as a template for replication of the viral genome, leading to the formation of new viruses [ 89]. The high degree of conservation of integrase-active sites across many retroviruses suggests that FIV might also be sensitive to integrase inhibitors [ 90]. Integrase inhibitors act through inhibition of integration of the proviral DNA that is produced by reverse transcription of the viral RNA genome [ 91].
